posts.description:
So, Alaska.
My friends @forestwoodward, @grahamzimmerman and I set up camp after being dropped off by Paul and his airplane-on-mega-wide-powder-skis.
This spot is called the Root Canal. Heard of it? It's not a very popular ski destination. 
But, more about that later.

Alaska didn't go as planned for me, forcing me to cancel my part in a dream journey with @salomonfreeski immediately following it. Instead, I hightailed it to Mexico in an attempt to thaw out some frozen capillaries and nerves.
It didn't work.

Watching @carolinegleich speak during the MASSIVE #marchforscience in SLC yesterday alongside @rob.lea and thousands of our closest friends. Thanks for standing up for intelligence, SLC! 
Rob, Caroline, and I will join more @protectourwinters members at the #peoplesclimatemarch in Washington DC on Saturday.
Where did you march yesterday, and where will you be on Saturday?
(Taken with @garmin VIRB, #garminpro)

You guys, I have to confess: I've been training. 2017 has already seen me home in SLC more than all of 2016 combined. And I've used that time wisely, preparing for...now. I'm leaving for a few consecutive trips, starting with one I've really been anticipating. 
I'm heading to Alaska to link with two dudes very important to me, @grahamzimmerman & @forestwoodward. We are going into the Alaska Range with wide eyes and an abundance of pent-up psych.
We will be living in a little tent on a big glacier. 
The plan is to be flexible; climb ice, rocks, and snow; and ski. And there's this one line...this one line...well, I'll tell you about it when we come off the glacier in a few weeks.
(...and to think that this gear I'm bringing doesn't include the majority of our climbing hardware, cooking or camping gear, or food.)
My immense gratitude to @garmin, @salomonfreeski, @goalzero, and the support of @blackdiamond, @clifbar, @backcountry & @expedusa.
I hope your next few weeks are fun. We will be cold and, hopefully, pushing hard. 
Much love. -brody
Up here, the line between success and failure can be thin.

Waking up to go walking up. 
This morning, with @carolinegleich.

See Peter up there?
Cranking air conditioning on the way to the ice climbing crag, @pvintoniv and I didn't know what to expect. "Tough to climb when it's 65 degrees and sunny?" I said. 
But after a pitch of thin ice, we decided to do something a bit more seasonally appropriate. 
Thanks for the waterfall inspiration (frozen and otherwise), @andrew_burr.
Wishing each of you a nice weekend. I suggest you make a little time to get outside. I dare you to *gasp* SLEEP there.

Some folks were recently asking what I include in the emergency kit that goes with me every day—ice climbing, rock climbing, or skiing. I’m sure it isn’t perfect for each activity, but the fact that it fits into a small dry bag means that I will move it between backpacks, ignore its weight, and actually take it with me. It is low-maintenance, organized, and tight.
It's referenced in the article @outsidemagazine recently interviewed me for, "5 Packing Tips from Outdoor Pros," linked in my profile.
These products have been selected pretty carefully from the numerous first aid courses I've completed over the past 11 years and the emergencies I'm most likely to encounter in the mountains. Considering I am very weight-conscious, scrutiny has been placed on each. There is plenty to be critiqued and discussed here--especially in regards to the countless other items that could potentially be helpful in the backcountry--and I am totally receptive to your opinions, as always. 
This is the kit that I feel comfortable using and is, more importantly, an amount of weight I'm willing to bring each day. For trips and expeditions, it is expanded. But it is never pared down. 
This is my kit. And I've very rarely had to actually use it. 
Because the best first aid kit is the one I have with me.

It seems as though there is this misconception that, just because we like skiing, means we love being cold. 
I don't. 
I've frostbitten my nose, toes, and fingers during a specific season of multiple trips to the arctic. It sucked. And now the cold hurts even more.
An equally pressing concern is heat. Since I spend the majority of my ski days hiking uphill as quickly as I can, I get sweaty. Even on cold days, I'll be in a long sleeve t-shirt, mesh @salomonfreeski hat, light gloves, short baselayer bottoms, breathable softshell snowpants, and the thinnest socks I can find. 
This way, I sweat less. Less sweat is less moisture to freeze when I stop to turn up the Notorious BIG anthology or NPR podcast blasting from my chest pocket. A thin hood goes up and down to regulate initial discomfort. Next, gloves go on and off, clipped to a @blackdiamond carabiner on my pack's waistbelt, to further do the trick. 
To keep moving, and thus not get cold, I try to eliminate any layer changes aside from my jacket at the top and bottom of the mountain. The hood and gloves I can manage without skipping a step.
I've found temperature regulation to be my biggest trick to staying efficient. As soon as I get too sweaty and uncomfortable, I think about being sweaty and hot and start sweating more, and then unwillingly slow my pace. 
I don't like being cold. Or hot. But juuussttt right. Yknow, cause I'm human.
If you watch my instastories, you'll see a lot of hood on/off throughout the course of a ski tour.

That's the MOON over @thomaswoodson. 
Why?
Because I hate dawn patrol, love sleep, enjoy breakfast, and sometimes don't start skinning until 4pm.
